results.title: [Melbourne Zoological Gardens]
results.brief_description: An observational documentary of the Melbourne Zoo. The film features the Zoo as a visitor attraction focusing on the interests of children. Children’s verbal observations form a large part of this otherwise non-narrated film. Various animals are shown in their enclosures and the film takes us on the Zoo train tour. Photography: Graeme Jackson and Philip Cordingley

results.title: [Maya Deren Compilation]
results.brief_description: A collection of films of Maya Deren. 1. “Private Life of a Cat” An animal’s outlook on life, narrated by Maya Deren, but directed by Alexander Hammid; 2. “Study in Choreography” A dancer moves across a land scape; 3. “Very Eye of Night” Dancers performing in negative; 4. “Meditation on Violence” A young Oriental man performs shadowboxing; 5. “Ritual in Transfigured Time” Movements of the dancers are merged with a variety of photographic effects.

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
This film is a vignette of family life in the suburbs, including a backyard barbeque and a trip to the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show. There are good examples of men’s, women’s and children’s fashion of the 1960s. This glimpse of the Royal Melbourne Show is a nostalgic journey back in time.

The title on the film can indicates that it is 1966 and Joy’s party.

We see a backyard gathering with adults and children. It is possibly a birthday party. Maurie drinks beer and poses for the camera. He and Val share a kiss and tend to the barbeque. To the amusement of others, one party goer bursts into a spontaneous dance sequence. In the background we see a Hills Hoist clothes line and what could possibly be an outhouse, or outdoor toilet. Handwritten humorous signs are displayed in various locations around the backyard. One sign reads “To Be Seen Stand Up, To be Heard Speak Up, To be Appreciated, Shut Up”.

There is a trip to the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show. The film shows signage for Peter’s Ice Cream, Coca-Cola and Four N Twenty Snack Bar. A man on stilts walks in front of the Four N Twenty Snack Bar sign. The children eat toffee apples and explore the sights, including the entrance to the animal pavilion at the show.

The film finishes with images of signs advertising Ross Wylie, Graham Chapman and Mike Furber, who were a part of the popular music scene in Australia at the time. There is also a graphic sign which reads “the Up and Coming of Stage Radio, Stars of Sunshine Records”.

Originally made on 8mm film.

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
This film shows suburban street scenes, a trip to the country and a visit to an animal shelter. There are good examples of 1960s fashion, suburban architecture and cars reflective of the era.

The film opens with Maurie and friends playfully posing with each other and performing for the camera in a tree-lined suburban street, possibly in Albert Park.

The friends all get into a Morris Major Elite (1962-1964) waving as they drive down the street past a Chrysler AP2 Royal (1958-1961). Single-story terrace houses can be seen in the background.

The family makes a stop-over at a cat and kitten shelter. A handwritten sign scrawled across the side of the building reads: “All cats and kittens in the hostel are stray and unwanted. Their health cannot be guaranteed. Please consult your vet and have your cat immunised immediately”. Beside the writing there is another sign reading “Kindly give a donation thank you”. Val plays with a kitten and presumably adopts it as she carries it into their car.

Families enjoy a couple of trips to the country, including a picnic under pine trees. A small boy attempts to climb one of the trees with hands-on assistance from Maurie. Val swings from a branch, flailing her legs comically. Lunch is cooked on a portable tripod-style wood-fuelled barbeque, while people sit in plastic banana lounges and picnic chairs. There is general banter and typical outdoor revelry among the friends. A large, non-functioning steam train serves as an improvised playground for the children.

Originally made on 8mm film.
